A family of sets indexed in a set I is defined to be a set S equipped with a function \pi _S\colon S \to I. For i\in I, we will write S_i\subseteq S for the inverse image \pi _S^*{\mathopen {}\left \{i\right \}\mathclose {}}\subseteq S:
Thus S is the disjoint union of all the S_i.

Let I be a set, and let \mathtt {P}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathtt {x},\mathtt {y}\right )\mathclose {}} be a formula in the language of set theory such that \forall i\in I\mathpunct {.} \exists ! S\mathpunct {.} \mathtt {P}{\mathopen {}\left (i,S\right )\mathclose {}} holds. Then the collection of sets S such that \mathtt {P}{\mathopen {}\left (i,S\right )\mathclose {}} holds for some i\in I holds forms a set.

This is almost saying that the direct image of I under \mathtt {P} is a set, but this doesn’t actually make sense because we do not have a way to speak about a “relation” between a set and the class of all sets. This strange situation is clarified by other foundational system that go beyond the limitations of the Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory that we have studied in this course.

In Lecture 18 we learned about injective and surjective functions. In this section, we will see that any function f\colon A\to B can be factored as the composition of a surjection followed by an injection.
Let f\colon A\to B be an arbitrary function. The image of f in defined to be the subset \mathrm {Im}(f)\subseteq B spanned by the values of f:
We may at times write m_f\colon \mathrm {Im}(f)\hookrightarrow B for the subset inclusion, which is an injective function.
A function f\colon A\to B also restricts to a function onto its image. In particular, we have:

In fact, e_f is a surjection. To see that this is the case, we fix an element b\in \mathrm {Im}(f) and we must find an element a\in A such that f(a)=b. But by definition of images, we know that b is of the form f(a) for some a so we are done.
Furthermore, function f\colon A\to B is equal to the composite m_f\circ e_f as can be quickly seen: given a\in A we compute m_f(e_f(a)) = m_f(f(a)) = f(a).
Given any set A, there can be no surjection from A to \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (A\right )\mathclose {}}.

Assume that we do have a surjection e\colon A\twoheadrightarrow \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (A\right )\mathclose {}}. Consider the subset U\in \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (A\right )\mathclose {}} defined below:
Because e\colon A\twoheadrightarrow \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (A\right )\mathclose {}} is surjective, we may find some a\in A such that e{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}}=U.

Thus for each x\in A, we have
x\in e{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}} \Longleftrightarrow x\in U \Longleftrightarrow x\not \in e{\mathopen {}\left (x\right )\mathclose {}} . Setting x:= a, we have a\in e{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}} \Longleftrightarrow a\not \in e{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}}, a contradiction.
The set \mathbb {R} of real numbers is uncountable.

Of course, as \mathbb {R} is non-empty, it is enough to show that it is not enumerable. We know that \mathbb {R}\cong {\mathopen {}\left [0,1\right ]\mathclose {}}\cong {\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {N}\to {\mathopen {}\left [2\right ]\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}\cong \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathbb {N}\right )\mathclose {}}, and and it follows from Theorem that the latter is not enumerable.
Let \prec \colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A be a relation on a set A.

html:ol.html:li: An element m\in S\subseteq A is a \prec -minimal (henceforth, “minimal”) element of S when \lnot {\mathopen {}\left (\exists x\in S\mathpunct {.} x\prec m\right )\mathclose {}}.
The binary relation \prec on A is called well-founded whenever each non-empty subset of A has a minimal element.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The “strictly less-than” relation <\colon \mathbb {N}\mathbin {\nrightarrow }\mathbb {N} is well-founded.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A non-well-founded relation on the integers

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The strictly less-than relation <\colon \mathbb {Z}\mathbin {\nrightarrow }\mathbb {Z} is not well-founded.
There is no smallest integer, so the set \mathbb {Z} has no <-minimal element.

fr:title.text: Characterisation of well-foundness in terms of chains

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Characterisation of well-foundness in terms of chains

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A relation \prec \colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A is well-founded if and only if there are no infinite descending \prec -chains in A, i.e. no infinite sequences a_0,a_1,\ldots ,a_i,\ldots such that a_0\succ a_1\succ \cdots a_i\succ \cdots .

Let \prec \colon A\mathbin {\nrightarrow } A be a well-founded relation and fix a subset S\subseteq A. Then A\subseteq S holds if and only if for each x\in A such that \forall y\in A\mathpunct {.} y\prec x\implies y\in S, we have x\in S.
In other words, to show that every element of A lies in S, it is enough to show that for any element x\in A, the elements below x lie in S.

One direction is trivial: suppose A\subseteq S and thus A=S, and fix x\in A such that \forall y\in A\mathpunct {.} y\prec x \implies y \in S holds. To show x\in S we use our assumption that A\subseteq S.
In the other direction, we suppose that for all x\in A such that \forall y\in A\mathpunct {.} y\prec x\implies y\in S we have x\in S. We need to show that A\subseteq S.
Fixing x\in A, we need to show that x\in S. Suppose to the contrary that x\not \in S. Then the complement A\setminus S is non-empty and therefore has a minimal element m\in A.
We will deduce that m\in S, which is contradictory. By assumption we have (\forall y\in A\mathpunct {.} y\prec m\implies y\in S)\implies m\in S\text {.}
It therefore sufices to prove the antecedent:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \forall y\in A\mathpunct {.} y\prec m \implies y\in S
fr:mainmatter.html:p: Fixing y\in A such that y\prec m, we see that y cannot lie outside S because it is smaller than m and m is the smallest element that lies outside S. Therefore, we have m\in S which contradicts our assumption m\not \in S.

The “strong” or “complete” induction principle for natural numbers states that for any subset S\subseteq \mathbb {N}, we have \forall x\in \mathbb {N}\mathpunct {.} x\in S if and only if we have 0\in S and, for any n\in \mathbb {N} such that m\in S for all m<n, we have n\in S. This is precisely the statement of well-founded induction for the strictly less-than relation.
